description: Oksana Lintz, after witnessing mounting unrest and confusion in Stenograd, uses her BCI access to request the system assemble public forums for citizens to openly share, verify, and debate personal histories.

The BCI suspends planned data releases and reallocates resources to coordinate district-wide assemblies. It develops an automated scoring system to visibly rate participants' honesty and empathy in real time.

District assemblies take place citywide. Ordinary and restored citizens speak, their histories and emotions scored and displayed live. The process draws large crowds, with many tense and emotional exchanges.

Increased scrutiny reveals inconsistencies and memory gaps in restored citizens during assemblies. The BCI's visible bias in score projections causes public accusations of some individuals being 'fabricated' or less real.

A wave of confessions and emotional breakdowns by restored citizens exposes systemic identity tampering. Stenograd begins compiling conflicting testimonies into a contested digital record, prompting citywide debate about memory and truth.
